awd_titl_txt: Conference: The 6th Stevens Conference on Bacteria-Material Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description:
This award supports the 6th Stevens Conference on Bacteria-Material Interactions to be held in May 2023 on the campus of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, New Jersey.  This conference attracts about 100 scientists, engineers, and clinician from across the country and world to better understand the problem of infection associated with tissue-contacting biomedical devices such as hip and knee replacements, heart valves, pacemakers, and hernia mesh, among many others.  Implant infection is a very significant problem because it usually cannot be cured simply by taking antibiotics.  Instead, the implanted device typically must be removed, and this can lead to a range of debilitating complications including death. NSF funding is being used to partially support the travel of a diverse group of as many as ten doctoral research students or advanced undergraduate research students who will present their research findings at the Conference. Participating in the Conference will help further their research and education and provide valuable networking and professional-development opportunities for them.

Technical Description:
This award supports the 6th Stevens Conference on Bacteria-Material Interactions to be held in May 2023 on the campus of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, New Jersey.  This conference series began in 2011 and has developed into one of the more visible scientific venues for advancing the field of device-associated infection.  The Conference addresses such topics as: clinical needs and challenges; fundamentals of bacteria/material and cell/material interactions; the design and testing of differentially interactive surfaces; and translational issues associated with the development of combination medical devices. The Conference convergently assembles leading experts in the various disciplines addressing this problem to define current and anticipated challenges that must be overcome in order to advance the field. Its specific aims are to: assess contemporary cross-disciplinary thinking; define multiple perspectives needs/directions for the overall field; train stakeholders across basic and translational thinking; and provide broad networking and teambuilding opportunities for all stakeholder groups. NSF funds will be used to partially support the travel costs for a diverse and interdisciplinary group of as many as ten doctoral and advanced-undergraduate research students to attend the Conference to present their research findings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided funds to partially offset travel expenses for nine doctoral students to attend the 6th Stevens Conference on Bacteria-Material Interactions. This two-day conference was held on the campus of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, New Jersey. It focused on infection associated with tissue-contacting biomedical devices such as hip and knee prostheses, catheters, pacemakers, and hernia mesh, among many other such devices. This is a compelling problem with substantial impact both on patient well-being and on the healthcare system. The technical focus of the 6th Conference centered on convergence between the many different stakeholder groups - patients, clinicians, device manufacturers, regulatory agencies, insurers, and academicians - in order to devise next-generation approaches to prevent, detect, or cure device-associated infection. The conference involved over 100 attendees from 8 countries. There were 22 invited oral presentations, 44 poster presentations, and a panel discussion.

Six of the nine student awardees came from the United States.  The other three came from Canada, Portugal, and Australia. Each of the nine made a presentation, either oral or poster or both. The small size and focused technical nature of the conference afforded these, and the many other student attendees, ample opportunity for learning experiences. The many breaks, meals, and social activities furthermore afforded them many opportunities for networking and professional development. In this regard the conference played a significant role in national/international workforce development in the important discipline of infection-resisting biomaterials.
